abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Mahakali
            Irrigation Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The project
            achieved its main objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is likely,
            and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, participation of beneficiaries in the
            design, construction, implementation, and O&M from the
            outset is very important, especially in large public
            irrigation systems. Second, service charges to cover full
            O&M costs of public utilities after improvement must be
            imposed and considered as a national policy in any
            investment project. Third, economic analysis before
            implementation of FMIS sub-projects was often inadequate.
            HMGN must take steps to ensure rigorous appraisal of future
            schemes' viability. Fourth, it is not reasonable to
            expect increased agricultural extension input from the DADO
            if additional resources are not allocated to DADO for this
            purpose. Finally, the WUA's responsibility for the
            O&M of new schemes must be carefully and clearly defined
            at the outset.

18152172.theme: Rural services and infrastructure,Rural policies and institutions,Natural disaster management
18152172.majtheme: Rural development,Social protection and risk management

abstracts.cdata!:
This project comprises four separate
            components. First, the loan will finance the Mahakali
            irrigation stage ll project, which involves the construction
            of irrigation and drainage facilities to serve an additional
            6,800 ha under the Mahakali irrigation project. Second, an
            irrigation line of credit pilot project,  which will finance
            subprojects for the construction of new small and medium
            surface and groundwater irrigation schemes, and the
            rehabilitation of existing surface schemes to cover a total
            of about 9,000 ha, these schemes will be operated and
            maintained by farmer groups. Third, the project will finance
            an emergency flood rehabilitation works to repair
            flood-damaged irrigation and river control facilities.
            Finally, the project will provide institutional development
            support to assist the Department of Irrigation to strengthen
            it's capability for sector program development and implementation.
